Title: Researchers Try to Head Off “Murder Hornets” Coming into US
Summary: Asian giant hornets were found for the first time in Washington State and could reemerge in the spring.

Title: Genomics Reveals How Humans Can Inadvertently Drive Plant Mimicry
Summary: Hand weeding of fields spurred an interloper to evolve a rice-like appearance, researchers conclude.

Title: Variation in Cannabis Testing Challenges a Young Industry
Summary: The US lacks standardized methods to assess products for potency and safety. That’s a big problem for the labs tasked with doing the testing.

Title: Image of the Day: Dog Detectives
Summary: Trained canines are remarkably accurate at detecting a pathogen that has devastated citrus crops.

Title: Infographic: Preventing a Swine Pandemic
Summary: With millions of pigs killed due to a major outbreak of African swine fever virus in Asia, researchers have intensified efforts to find a vaccine quickly.

Title: Infographic: The Lifecycle of African Swine Fever Virus
Summary: Understanding how domestic pigs can be infected with the deadly virus could be key to protecting them from it.

Title: Infographic: A Deadly Pig Virus’s Escapes from Africa
Summary: African swine fever virus has left the continent on three occasions, causing outbreaks in Europe, the Americas, and most recently, East Asia.

Title: Can a Vaccine Save the World’s Pigs from African Swine Fever?
Summary: A devastating outbreak of the virus across East Asia has made the long-neglected pathogen a top research priority, but many challenges lie ahead.

Title: Yellow Dye in Turmeric Linked with Lead Poisoning in Bangladesh
Summary: Scientists track the spice from the soil to the market to pinpoint the source of contamination in pregnant women’s blood.

Title: Image of the Day: Fragmented Habitat
Summary: Human activities may be affecting both narrow-ranged plants and widespread ones.

Title: Eavesdropping on Soil Insects Could Aid Pest Management
Summary: Insects in the soil are difficult to monitor, but listening in on the noises they make could help farmers detect pest infestations and improve estimates of biodiversity.

Title: The Long Road to Edible Cottonseed
Summary: The FDA recently cleared the way for marketing of the genetically modified product. Texas A&M’s Keerti Rathore speaks with The Scientist about why and how it was developed.

Title: Trump Administration Overturns Clean Water Regulation
Summary: The repeal will return the US to water standards from 1986.

Title: Image of the Day: Root Pottery
Summary: An agroecology grad student creates rhizosphere-inspired art.

Title: Dreaded Banana-Infecting Fungus Spreads to Latin America
Summary: Researchers confirm TR4’s presence in Colombia, increasing concerns about the future of the industry.

Title: Antibiotic Ineffective Against Citrus Greening: Study
Summary: Oxytetracycline, approved by the US government to combat citrus scourge, may not work—at least not as a spray.

Title: USDA Labs’ Move to Kansas City Might Be Illegal
Summary: An inspector general finds that the agency was supposed to have received congressional approval before relocating facilities out of Washington, DC.

Title: Image of the Day: Safety in Numbers
Summary: Male Asian elephants are forming long-term, all-male groups to forage in agricultural areas of India.

Title: EPA Will Not Ban Pesticide Linked to Neurological Issues
Summary: The agency argues that chlorpyrifos is one of few “cost-effective options” for controlling certain farm pests.

Title: Agriculture and Climate Shape Biodiversity on Mount Kilimanjaro
Summary: A six-year study across the Tanzanian mountain’s slopes hints at how land-use practices will interact with a changing climate to influence ecosystems around the world.

Title: Scientists Race to Build Vaccine for African Swine Fever
Summary: The devastating outbreak of the disease that has led to millions of pig deaths in East Asia has intensified efforts to develop a vaccine quickly, but the virus presents several challenges that are yet to be overcome.

Title: Opinion: Agriculture Must Replace Small Science with Big Science
Summary: Agronomic sciences should follow the lead of genetics and other disciplines in sharing data.

Title: Genetically Modified Wheat Found in a Field in Washington State
Summary: The unapproved crop is resistant to glyphosate in the weedkiller Roundup, but doesn’t seem to have entered the food supply.

Title: Couple With Cancer Wins $2 Billion in Case Against Monsanto
Summary: In determining that the illnesses came about from exposure to glyphosate in Roundup, a California jury delivers the biggest loss so far to the herbicide manufacturer in lawsuits about the product.

Title: California Seeks to Ban Chlorpyrifos-Containing Pesticides
Summary: The state’s Environmental Protection Agency says that evidence of the chemical’s link to neurological problems in children is overwhelming.

Title: Widespread Declines in UK’s Pollinators: Study
Summary: Over 30 years, one-third of the wild bees and hoverfly species surveyed sustained losses, likely due to pesticides, habitat loss, and climate change.

Title: Softer Diets Allowed Early Humans to Pronounce “F,” “V” Sounds
Summary: Drastic dietary changes during the agricultural revolution altered the configuration of the human bite, paving the way for new sounds in spoken language, a new study finds.

Title: Opinion: GE Crops Are Seen Through a Warped Lens
Summary: Risks that pertain to all manner of new crops are often misattributed to genetic engineering. This distorts the public’s view of the technology.

Title: Image of the Day: Corn Fed
Summary: Bumblebee colonies grow poorly in landscapes dominated by maize, researchers find.

Title: Industry-Funded Pesticide Data Problematic, Study Shows
Summary: Scrutinizing a company’s study on a widely used pesticide, chlorpyrifos, academic researchers find shortcomings in analyses and public disclosures of results.

Title: Pesticide Exposure Alters Bumblebees’ Behavior in Their Nests
Summary: A high-tech approach to monitoring bee activity inside the nest reveals how the neonicotinoid imidacloprid impairs colony growth.

Title: USDA Approves Edible Cotton
Summary: While farmers have the green light to grow the genetically engineered plant, FDA approval is still needed before the seeds are sold as food.

Title: Deadly Swine Disease Spreads Among Pigs in China
Summary: Tens of thousands of hogs are being slaughtered to stop its spread.

Title: Climate Change Likely to Ding Beer Supply
Summary: The average price of a pint could double by the end of this century because of declines in barley yields, a study predicts.

Title: Questions Raised About DARPA-Funded Crop Program
Summary: Critics of an agricultural research initiative cite concerns about possible weaponization of the resulting technology, which would use infected insects to deliver genetically modified viruses to plants.

Title: Celebrated Brazilian Bee Scientist Warwick Kerr Dies
Summary: Revered as a humanitarian and scientist, Kerr was also blamed for the introduction of aggressive Africanized bees to the Americas.

Title: Entire Bread Wheat Genome Fully Annotated
Summary: It took an international group of researchers 13 years to crack the code and their efforts are already bearing fruit—one study has pinned down the genes responsible for wheat allergies and sensitivity.

Title: Reorganization of USDA Research Offices Concerns Scientists
Summary: The plan would move two scientific branches out of Washington, DC, by 2019.

Title: New Pesticide Affects Bumblebee Reproduction
Summary: Sulfoxaflor, an alternative insect-killer to older chemicals that decimate pollinators, turns out to kneecap colonies.

Title: Florida Is Having a 10-Month Streak of Toxic Red Tide
Summary: Can clay particles, ozone, or phages stop the algae bloom that is killing wildlife and posing a health risk to humans?

Title: Mutated Gene Could Raise Marine Mammals’ Vulnerability to Pesticides
Summary: The resulting lost protein, PON1, breaks down organophosphates in land mammals.

Title: Scientists Can’t Agree on What’s Making Pistachio Trees Sick
Summary: A new study ignites debate on the cause of pistachio bushy top syndrome, a disease that has crippled farms in California, Arizona, and New Mexico.

Title: Image of the Day: A-maize-ing!
Summary: By combining alleles involved in plant height, an agricultural scientist has grown the world’s tallest cornstalk, breaking his own record set in 2017.

Title: Organic Fertilizers Rife With Microplastics: Study
Summary: Converting biowaste to plant food is an overlooked source of tiny plastic pollutants, researchers say.

Title: Russian Sites Promote Anti-GMO Articles, Study Finds
Summary: RT and Sputnik publish stories about GMOs more often than US outlets, and typically portray them in a negative light.

Title: Book Excerpt from How to Feed the World
Summary: In chapter 5, “The Technology Ticket,” contributing author Uris Baldos urges acceptance and investment in “precision agriculture” to provide for a burgeoning global population.

Title: How Toxic is the World’s Most Popular Herbicide Roundup?
Summary: Glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup, is designed to be toxic to plants, but scientists observe some untoward effects on animals in the lab.

Title: Image of the Day: Colorado Potato Beetles
Summary: Leptinotarsa decemlineata has been decimating agricultural crops since at least the 19th century, and by sequencing its genome researchers hope to explore new strategies for controlling the pest.

Title: Contributors
Summary: Meet some of the people featured in the February 2018 issue of The Scientist.

Title: Anjali Iyer-Pascuzzi Investigates How Pathogens Invade Plant Roots
Summary: The Purdue University researcher is one of the first to examine the molecular processes that underlie infection by soil microbes.

Title: Agricultural Technology Can Save Humanity from Starvation (Again)
Summary: We are on the cusp of yet another revolution in how we feed the populace.

Title: Researchers Learn from Plant Viruses to Protect Crops
Summary: Plants are locked in an ancient arms race with hostile viruses, but genome editing is giving crops the upper hand.

Title: Infographic: Plants’ Microbial Communities
Summary: Like animals, plants host communities of microbes that influence a wide variety of their biological processes.

Title: How Viruses Attack Plants
Summary: Viruses are incapable of reproducing without the help of a host, whose cells copy their genetic material and fabricate the building blocks of new virus particles.

Title: Growing Awareness
Summary: University of California, Riverside, plant biologist Katie Dehesh explains the importance of agricultural research.

Title: Breakthrough Prizes Recognize Geneticists, Big Bang Researchers
Summary: Among this year’s winners are a geneticist who revealed how plants respond to shade and a group of physicists who mapped the universe’s background radiation.

Title: European Commission Grants Five-Year License Renewal for Glyphosate
Summary: The approval of the Roundup ingredient follows an extensive debate amidst conflicting evidence over the health effects of the world’s most popular weed killer.

Title: Long-term Study Finds That the Pesticide Glyphosate Does Not Cause Cancer
Summary: The report provides evidence that goes against concerns that Monsanto’s popular herbicide, Roundup, is carcinogenic.

Title: Washington State University Researchers Complain of Industry Influence
Summary: Agriculture faculty members allege funding from industry organizations is tied to their employment status.

Title: Pesticide Residues Linked to Unsuccessful IVF
Summary: Women who ate more produce known to harbor pesticides were less likely to succeed with fertility treatment than women who ate fewer of these fruits and vegetables.

Title: WHO Cherry-Picked Data on Pesticide, Investigation Finds
Summary: A group evaluating glyphosate’s cancer risk omitted evidence that the chemical is not carcinogenic.

Title: Insects Are Increasingly Evolving Resistance to Genetically Modified Crops
Summary: Plantings of non-GM refuges counter the development of resistance.

Title: Infographic: Evolving Virulence
Summary: Tracking the myxoma virus in the wild rabbit populations of Australia has yielded insight into how pathogens and their hosts evolve.

Title: Trump Nominates Sam Clovis to Lead USDA Research
Summary: The choice of an economics professor and climate change denialist is slammed by science advocates.

Title: Bacteriophages to the Rescue
Summary: Phage therapy is but one example of using biological entities to reduce our reliance on antibiotics and other failing chemical solutions.

Title: First Genetic Screen of Pigs Using ENU
Summary: Using the mutagenic chemical N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea, researchers confirm the role of a gene in a piglet deformity and identify potential models for human diseases.

Title: Opinion: Hidden Environmental Cost in Green Solutions
Summary: The inclusion of soil nutrient fluxes is critical for more-accurately assessing the societal value of ethanol biofuel vs. corn feed.

Title: Field Studies Confirm Neonicotinoids’ Harm to Bees
Summary: Two large studies find that, in real-world conditions, the insecticides are detrimental to honey bees and bumblebees.

Title: Uncovering the Secrets of a Successful Pest
Summary: The green peach aphid can colonize new host plants with ease through rapid changes in gene expression.

Title: 45 Feet High and Rising
Summary: Maize enthusiast Jason Karl aims to continue breaking his own records for the tallest corn plants ever grown.

Title: Record-Setting Corn Grows 45 Feet Tall
Summary: A plant breeder succeeds in growing a huge maize plant thanks to a known mutation and a few environmental tricks.

Title: Andrea Eveland Teases Apart Gene Networks in Crop Plants
Summary: The Donald Danforth Plant Science Center researcher links complex traits to the genes that underlie them.

Title: Improving Tomato Flavor, Genetically
Summary: A sequencing blitz on the tomato genome reveals the genes that contribute most to tastiness.

Title: Superbug Gene Found on Pig Farm
Summary: Evidence of resistance to a “last-resort” drug for antibiotic-resistant bacteria is discovered among farm animals for the first time.

Title: Plant Biologist Killed in Ethiopian Protest
Summary: Stone throwers hit the car Sharon Gray was riding in while visiting the country for a meeting.

Title: Science History: The First Transgenic Arabidopsis
Summary: Tweaks to a transformation protocol in 1986 cemented the little plant's mighty role in plant genetics research.

Title: Monsanto Buys Rights to CRISPR
Summary: The US agribusiness secures a global, nonexclusive licensing agreement from the Broad Institute to use the gene-editing technology for agricultural applications.

Title: Bayer Looks to Buy Monsanto
Summary: The US agribusiness behemoth agreed to a $57 billion buyout offer from the European pharmaceutical giant.

Title: Protein or Perish
Summary: A bacteriophage must evolve certain variants of a protein or die.

Title: Donor-Soil Microbes Drive Ecosystem Restoration
Summary: Excavating existing topsoil and adding donor soil, researchers revitalized degraded farmland in the span of six years.

Title: Nobel Laureates vs. Greenpeace
Summary: Dozens of Nobel Prize winners pen an open letter, calling on the environmental organization to stop spreading false claims regarding genetically modified organisms.

Title: Study: Farming Arose Twice in the Ancient Middle East
Summary: Ancient DNA research suggests that there were two independent agricultural revolutions more than 10,000 years ago.

Title: Antibiotic Affects Cow Dung
Summary: Researchers assess some of the downstream effects of treating livestock with a broad-spectrum antibiotic.

Title: E.U. Delays Vote on Roundup
Summary: Newly published research on the key ingredient in the Monsanto-made weed killer is holding up lawmakers’ decisions on whether to continue to allow its sale in Europe.

Title: Report: Still Lots to Learn About GE Crops
Summary: A National Academies–led analysis evaluates the impacts of genetically engineered crops—and calls for updated regulations.

Title: Genetically Engineered Hornless Dairy Calves
Summary: Researchers use a gene editor to introduce an allele that eliminates the horned trait—and thus, the need for an expensive and painful process of dehorning—in dairy cows.

Title: Speaking of Science
Summary: February 2016's selection of notable quotes

Title: Gene Editing Without Foreign DNA
Summary: Scientists perform plant-genome modifications on crops without using plasmids.

Title: GM Calves Move to University
Summary: The first two bulls genetically engineered to lack horns arrived at the University of California, Davis, for breeding.

Title: The Unregulation of Biotech Crops
Summary: Genetic engineering—once a trigger for federal oversight—is now ushering some modified crops around scrutiny.

Title: Farming Sped Eurasian Evolution
Summary: New clues from ancient DNA reveal the remarkable effect of agriculture on adaptation in Stone Age humans who lived across Europe.

Title: One-Third of Cactus Species Threatened
Summary: A global assessment of declining cacti populations places responsibility on increasing human activities.

Title: Capsule Reviews
Summary: Brain Storms, Orphan, Maize for the Gods, and Paranoid.

Title: Scientists Oppose Scotland’s GM Crop Ban
Summary: Researchers from across the U.K. draft a letter criticizing the recent decision to keep genetically modified crops out of Scotland.

Title: Genome Digest
Summary: What researchers are learning as they sequence, map, and decode species’ genomes

Title: Scotland Nixing GM Crops
Summary: The country will opt-out of growing genetically modified foods that have been approved for cultivation in the European Union.

Title: Judge Decides on GM Rice Retraction
Summary: Ethical breaches in a study on the benefits of so-called “golden rice” lead to the paper being pulled from the literature.

Title: Building Bigger Beefsteaks
Summary: Understanding the genetics of stem cell population maintenance in plants producing jumbo tomatoes could help scientists generate more-massive fruits.

Title: Silence of the Lambs
Summary: A die-off of newborn lambs in Australia leads to the discovery of a new toxin and clues to a devastating liver disease in children.

Title: Bees Drawn to Pesticides
Summary: One study shows the insects prefer food laced with pesticides, while another adds to the evidence that the chemicals are harmful to some pollinators.

Title: Study: Pesticides Harm Bees
Summary: A researcher challenges the UK government’s conclusion that neonicotinoids aren’t that bad for pollinators.

Title: Reading Between the Pages
Summary: Researchers at Trinity College Dublin and the University of York excavate the genetic secrets contained in the DNA of old parchments.

Title: Slip Me Some Skin
Summary: Scientists tracing the history of livestock breeding probe parchment documents for genetic information.

Title: Opinion: On Global GMO Regulation
Summary: Advances in genome-editing technologies have made modifying crops easier than ever before. They’ve also clouded the already murky realm of genetically modified foods.

Title: USDA Approves Genetically Engineered Apples
Summary: Apples genetically modified to resist browning can be commercially planted in the U.S., the government ruled last week.

Title: Corn Chronicle
Summary: A genetic analysis of ancient and modern maize clarifies the crop’s checkered domestication history.

Title: Along Came a Spider
Summary: Researchers are turning to venom peptides to protect crops from their most devastating pests.

Title: Barley Key to Mankind’s Alpine Incursion
Summary: The cold-tolerant cereal crop allowed humans to live and farm higher than ever starting more than 3,000 years ago.

Title: GMO Bans in Europe May Progress
Summary: An environmental committee of the European Parliament approves a measure to allow members states to ban genetically engineered crops.

Title: Ancient Europeans Were Lactose Intolerant
Summary: Five-thousand years after agricultural practices spread across Neolithic Europe, human populations remained unable to digest sugars from the milk of mammals.

Title: 360-Degree View of the Tomato
Summary: Researchers have sequenced 360 varieties of the tomato plant to create a comprehensive map of the evolution of the fruit from its wild form to the modern varieties.

Title: Opinion: The Planet Needs More Plant Scientists
Summary: Academia is not producing sufficient PhDs in the plant sciences to solve the crop production challenges facing a rapidly growing population.

Title: Bird Diversity Drops From Forests to Farms
Summary: Farms support less phylogenetically diverse bird populations than forests, but some farms are better than others.

Title: Light-Tolerant Tomatoes
Summary: Upping the expression of a single gene improves the plant’s ability to withstand light and increases yields.

Title: Opinion: Bumblebees in Trouble
Summary: Commercialization has sickened wild bumblebees around the world. Can we save them?

Title: Rusty Waves of Grain
Summary: See how a ruinous fungus that attacks wheat wreaks its damage.

Title: Wheat Whisperer, circa 1953
Summary: The Green Revolution of the 20th century began with Norman Borlaug’s development of a short-statured, large-grained wheat.

Title: Wild Relatives
Summary: As rich sources of genetic diversity, the progenitors and kin of today’s food crops hold great promise for improving production in agriculture’s challenging future.

Title: Putting Up Resistance
Summary: Will the public swallow science’s best solution to one of the most dangerous wheat pathogens on the planet?

Title: Designer Livestock
Summary: New technologies will make it easier to manipulate animal genomes, but food products from genetically engineered animals face a long road to market.

Title: Agricultural Pest Out-Evolves GM Crop
Summary: The corn rootworm has become resistant to a genetically modified maize variety that produces an insecticidal toxin.

Title: E.U. Pushes Forward With GM Corn
Summary: The European Commission is set to approve a new strain of genetically modified maize despite opposition from member nations.

Title: Biodiversity = More (and Better) Coffee
Summary: Study finds that coffee plants grown in the vicinity of Mount Kilimanjaro produce more coffee beans of a better quality if they are surrounded by thriving plant and animal communities.

Title: New Suspect in Bee Colony Collapse
Summary: A virus that causes blight in plants may contribute the catastrophic decline of honeybee colonies.

Title: Herding Cats
Summary: Examination of bones found in a Chinese village suggests that domesticated felines lived side-by-side with humans 5,300 years ago.

Title: Microbial Terroir
Summary: Researchers show that microbes on the surface and stems of wine grapes are nonrandomly associated with the plant’s variety and geographic region.

Title: Fungus Versus Plant
Summary: The crop-destroying gray mold fungus uses RNA weapons to disable plant defenses and invade.

Title: Going Viral
Summary: Bacteriophages shuttle genes between diverse ecosystems.

Title: Opinion: Restoring Tomato Flavor
Summary: Commercial tomatoes rarely have that fresh vine-ripened flavor that everyone loves, but the ideal recipe for tomato taste is now known. Will growers embrace the new cultivars?

Title: Fungus-Fighting Genes
Summary: Two genes from wild relatives of wheat could save domestic wheat from fungal destruction.

Title: Ripening Genes Pegged
Summary: Researchers identify thousands of plant genes activated by the gaseous hormone ethylene, which influences ripening, pathogen defense, growth regulation, and more.

Title: Making Good on Research
Summary: Scientists working in developing nations who engage in capacity building find it bolsters the lives of locals and their own work.

Title: It Takes a Village
Summary: Scientists working in developing countries find that giving back to local communities enriches their own research.

Title: Ladybird Bioterrorists
Summary: The Asian harlequin ladybird carries a biological weapon to wipe out competing species.

Title: Sick Mold
Summary: A virus that infects a crop-killing fungus can spread freely, opening the possibility of its use as a fungicide.

Title: Fighting Microbes with Microbes
Summary: Doctors turn to good microbes to fight disease. Will the same strategy work with crops?

Title: Soil Bacteria May “Eat” Antibiotics
Summary: Long-term exposure to antibiotics from agricultural run off may encourage the evolution of soil bacteria that break down and consume the antibacterial agents.

Title: Opinion: Evolving CO2-Hungry Crops
Summary: Breeding plants that can convert more carbon dioxide to food could help feed a growing population.

Title: How Plants Feel
Summary: A hormone called jasmonate mediates plants' responses to touch and can boost defenses against pests.

Title: Ancient Butterball
Summary: The star of Thanksgiving was domesticated by Mayans 1,000 years earlier than previously thought.

Title: Coconut Gene Bank Threatened
Summary: A deadly bacterial disease is knocking at the door of a crucial collection of coconut palms in Papua New Guinea.

Title: Pigs Raise Blood Pressure
Summary: Residents surrounding strongly smelling hog farms experience higher blood pressure levels as the stench worsens.

Title: AAAS: Don't Label GM Foods
Summary: The American Association for the Advancement of Science says labeling genetically modified food products would be misleading.

Title: Proteinaceous Cassava Lacks Protein
Summary: A PLOS ONE study claiming to have jacked up the essential crop with a gene to allow the plant to produce protein is retracted.

Title: Agriculture-Ecology Initiative Announced
Summary: The US Department of Agriculture announces a partnership of 10 study sites to help promote long-term research.

Title: Down and Dirty
Summary: Diverse plant communities create a disease-fighting "soil genotype."

Title: War-born Climate Change
Summary: A nuclear war could have profound effects on crops yields around the world, according to a new study.

Title: Better Biofuel Crops
Summary: One way to increase biofuel production is to engineer plants that can withstand harsh environmental conditions, thereby expanding the range in which such crops can be grown.

Title: Biofuels by the Numbers
Summary: Of the many available no- or low-carbon methods to harvest energy, including wind, geothermal, hydroelectric, and solar approaches, conversion of plant biomass to liquid fuels is the most cost-effective strategy.

Title: Growing Better Biofuel Crops
Summary: Research is underway to reduce the use of food crops for biofuels by shifting to dedicated energy crops and agricultural residues.

Title: Food for Thought
Summary: Plant research remains grossly underfunded, despite the demand for increased crop production to support a growing population.

Title: Seeds Inherit Memories of Enemies
Summary: Infested plants pass on a defense memory of pests and pathogens to help the next generation withstand invasions.

Title: GM Crop Field Intruder Arrested
Summary: A protestor is arrested for trying to break into a field of genetically modified wheat at a UK agricultural research station.

Title: Revenge of the Weeds
Summary: Plant pests are evolving to outsmart common herbicides, costing farmers crops and money.

Title: Conventional Yields Trump Organic
Summary: A new meta-analysis of farming practices suggests that traditional methods of cultivating food plants result in heftier harvests than do organic strategies.

Title: Building a Better Sheep
Summary: Chinese scientists claim to have cloned a lamb carrying a roundworm gene that aids in the production of polyunsaturated fatty acids.

Title: Banned Antibiotics Found in Poultry
Summary: Researchers find evidence of illegal use of antibiotics in poultry products.

Title: Antibiotics in the Animals We Eat
Summary: Low-dose antibiotics in animal feed fuel drug-resistance in human infectious diseases.

Title: Banana Fungus Origin Revealed
Summary: A fungal disease that is plaguing banana plants around the world originated in South East Asia.

Title: FDA Curbs Livestock Antibiotics
Summary: The agency has limited the use of antibiotics in farm animals.

Title: Environmentally-Friendly Sheep?
Summary: A new model of sheep farming shows that genetic changes can help lower methane production, leading to lower greenhouse gas emission.

Title: Marriage Affects Crop Diversity?
Summary: Nuptial arrangements between members of African farming communities could have influenced the genetic diversity of the staple crop cassava.

Title: Bird Flu Vax Spurs Virus Evolution
Summary: Inadequate poultry immunization programs may cause higher mutations rates in the bird flu virus, rendering the vaccine ineffective and increasing the threat of cross-species transmission.

Title: Killing Pests by Disrupting Hibernation
Summary: New synthetic hormones can indirectly kill the corn earworm by disrupting its winter sleep habits.

Title: Big Boost to African Cassava Project
Summary: Philanthropic organizations devote millions to a research project aiming to develop genetically modified, virus-resistant versions of a Sub-Saharan staple crop.

Title: Opinion: The Water Deficit
Summary: Current farming practices draw too much of the world’s freshwater supplies to be sustainable. A change is needed to support growing agricultural demand.

Title: The Beginning of the End for Bananas?
Summary: Already reeling from a 20-year losing battle with a devastating disease, the banana variety eaten in the United States is now threatened by a new—but old—enemy.

Title: Opinion: Food Security Needs Sound IP
Summary: To meet the agricultural demands of the growing population, appropriate technology transfer incentives are a must.

Title: Anti-GM Vandals Destroy Crops
Summary: German and Australian activists opposed to genetically modified foods ruined experimental test beds of maize, wheat, and potatoes.

Title: Honey bee microbiome probed
Summary: Researchers reveal several new viruses lurking in healthy hives.

Title: Drought-tolerant corn trials underwater
Summary: Agribusiness giant Monsanto is finding out that it's difficult to conduct field trials of drought-resistant corn when it won't stop raining. The company hopes to launch a new line of corn seed that's been genetically engineered to thrive in drough conditions by 2013.

Title: Alternative Agriculture
Summary: The debate over genetically engineered crops rages on, but other technologies offer new hope for sustainable farming.

Title: Human Effects
Summary: Editor's Choice in Ecology

Title: The Coming Health Crisis
Summary: Indirect effects of global climate change threaten the health of hundreds of millions of people. The very uncertainty that shrouds this issue must serve as an organizing principle for adaptation to its ill effects.
